↑ Rambam Mitzvot (mitzvae) (English translation by Rabbi Eliyahu Touger), Mitzvot 1):
Mitzvot Commandments is a major category of halakhah (Jewish legal practice). According to traditional Jewish belief and understanding of Mitzvot commandments are considered not to be optional, and are compulsory on Jews. According to Maimonides these are categorized into these broad divisions:
Biblical commandments (עשרת הדברות, Eser Rabbah)
Commandments with rabbinic ordination (מצוֹת דרשות, Mitzvot D'rabbanan)
Commandments for all Jews (שמור שבת, shembat)
Commandments specific to Jews (מצוֹת קביעה, Mitzva Kavivah)
Korbanot mitzvot (קרבנות מצוות, Korbanot Mitzvot, Mitzvoh of sacrifice)
Mitzvoh of purification (קרבן הנילאת, Kohen Ha Nila)
Commandments for priests (כל מצוות מלאכים, Kol Ma'os Melachim)
Commandments for Jews in Exile (מצוֹת גלילה שביאלי, Mitzvah Galuilah SheB'Yei'li)
Commandments to bring joy and blessing on the People of Israel (מצויות יוצרין סלא, mizvar yotserin sesler)
Commandments that help preserve the commandments themselves (מצוות נפש, Mitzvah Nephesh)
Commandments that promote morality (מצוֹת אמונה, Mitzvah Emunah, moral/ethical commandments)

Many of us are afraid to start our own business. However, those who want to achieve their career goals should keep in mind that starting a business is not an easy task. It requires a lot of planning and commitment.
For those who do not feel like they can handle such difficult tasks, there are many resources available online to assist you. In fact, many people find it easier to work with a business consultant who offers their assistance in a variety of ways. Here are some tips on how you can hire a professional who will help you get started in the business. 1. First, you need to know how much the market is willing to pay you and what the market will offer you.
It is important that you are aware of the demand for your products so that you can decide how much you should charge for them. For example, if you are selling something on a daily basis, you may be able to earn $100 a day. If your business is a monthly or bi-annual arrangement, you may earn more than that depending on how well you meet the demand.
If there is not much demand, then it may be wise to sell products at lower prices in order to gain a stronger foothold in the market. 2. If you have a website, you need to ensure that the website is properly designed. A website that is good to look at is not always pleasant to use, which is why you have to make sure that your website is easy to navigate. You have to understand that your potential customers will not always go right to your website to make a decision about your products. This means that you can’t count on the customer to visit your site and look at the products for sale in order to make a choice.
You need to make sure that the pages have a clearly defined section so that people can easily get the information they want. 3. A successful marketing strategy involves the use of different promotional tools. In simple terms, promotion is the use of various techniques to draw attention to your business website. As previously stated, it is important that your website is visually attractive so that it is easy for the visitors to find what they need, and this is what promotion is all about.
To begin with, you have to select a platform that is able to provide the necessary promotion. If your website is only for the local visitors, it is better to select a platform that is targeted to a national or international audience. Therefore, you should not only be focusing on getting better visibility, but also getting more visitors as well. You can choose to go for a website builder because this is a widely used way of getting visibility. It is better to select the appropriate builder to ensure that you have an effective plan that will benefit your business.
4. If your website has any images or videos, you need to optimize them for search engines.
Search engines rank websites according to the quality and relevance to the target audience. Therefore, the more your site is relevant and informative, the better it will rank. In addition, it is important to ensure that your website has a great number of links. The reason for this is that people will often click on the links in order to get information or even make a purchase. As a result of this, you will have more people visiting your site and increasing the potential for your business to get more sales. 5.
Make sure that you are promoting your products and services properly on social media.
Social networking sites, such as Facebook and Twitter, are being used by millions of people. Therefore, you should also use these sites as a promotional tool. You can offer special deals or discounts for customers who buy your products on these networks. Make sure that you post your website links on your social media pages so that your followers know where to look for deals or for a certain product or service that you are selling.

As we all know, college is a time to have fun, to meet new people and to grow as a person. It’s also the time for you to start thinking about the things that will help you achieve your dreams in the future.
College is an exciting new experience for many students – it is where they learn to be independent, it is also their first contact with life outside the home and it is also an exciting opportunity to learn new things about themselves. So it’s no wonder that many university students find themselves worrying about how they will balance their studies and life outside of college, especially if they haven’t yet achieved their A-level qualifications.
This is a question that many parents start to ask themselves, “how to choose a good College.” A good College can open up a whole new world of opportunities for your child and help them gain a greater level of independence.
Investing in an education is something that people who are concerned about the future of the country consider very seriously. With the financial difficulties that many young people are facing today, it is not surprising that many parents are looking for ways to make their kids’ education as profitable as possible.
This is where the notion of choosing a College has come into the picture. Choosing a good College that will give your kid an education that will help them to become financially independent is just one of the many different ways that parents can do this.
In fact, choosing a good College can be even more difficult than finding a good school. This is because there are a large number of colleges, all offering different degrees and levels of excellence.
In order to make the decision about which College is right for your child, you will need to ask yourself a number of different questions. Firstly, you will need to ask yourself some questions about the standard of the College itself.
Can they offer you different degrees? If so, how much do they charge? Is there a need for a particular programme or curriculum that they do not offer? Do they have a good reputation in the country for teaching high quality courses?
How to choose a good college is also a question that many parents ask themselves as they try to come up with a list of possible colleges that they believe to be the best.
In order to answer this question, you will need to make some research before you can begin looking for a College.
In order to find out about the College, you can check out reviews that have been written by other parents. Make sure that the information that you gather from these reviews is reliable and that the College you are considering is based on actual facts.
This is especially important for the College that you want to send your child to. Some Colleges have been known to ‘market’ their courses, but other ones are true to their word and are only looking to attract people to their College.
Also, remember that the College you choose will also have to be able to meet your child’s personal needs.
You may be able to decide which class your child needs to take based on the information that you have gathered about the different curriculums. or even what level their degree will be by looking at the information on their application form.
Many colleges will list their degrees on their website and will give you the chance to make your own decisions about the classes that your child should take. The same is true for the College you choose. Make sure that the information that you receive is accurate. and that you can get a good idea about how much your child’s education is going to cost.
Another thing to consider when looking at how to choose a good college is the reputation of the schools that the college is affiliated with.
Just because the school is called an ‘accredited’ school does not mean that the College they are linked to is not trusted by the public.
This is another reason why you must do some research before you make a decision about which college to enrol your child in.
There are many advantages to choosing to enrol at a College affiliated with a highly reputable school. In addition to the fact that your child will receive a good education at a low cost, you will also be able to be confident that they will be safe and will be given the chance to progress in their own time. It is certainly well worth spending some time weighing up the advantages and disadvantages of different colleges before making any decision about which one to go to.
When choosing a particular course in college, it is wise to consider the school’s accreditation status from government agency or an independent accrediting agency.
Accreditation is an important aspect in College education and one that many institutions take pride in.
The process for reviewing and evaluating the performance of a particular school for which students are enrolled is known as Accreditation.
An Accreditation System may evaluate and determine the worthiness of a school based upon several aspects. They include the quality of instruction, the educational goals and objectives of the school, student progress in terms of coursework completion, and the extent to which the school is able to uphold its stated goals.
An accredited institution is one that has received approval from a certain government agency or independent agency. Accreditations are issued to the institution according to standards set forth by the organization or the independent group.
There are certain requirements that the students of the institution must meet to qualify for accreditation. The requirements typically include completion of a course in their major field of study, and the fulfillment of other specifications.
In addition, the level of the courses and the type of course work will depend on the accreditation status of the school.
Some schools are accredited by the U.S. Department of Education, the state of New Mexico, or both. These schools are often smaller and offer more opportunities to learn from other students and teachers than the larger institutions.
Most accredited institutions offer a wide variety of programs and courses so that students can select the type of coursework that will fit their career goals.
Accreditation status is an important factor for students and for parents when evaluating a potential college.
It is important for parents to ensure that the institution their child chooses is one that is accredited. Without this accreditation, students are unable to receive their degree, and may even be prevented from pursuing a graduate degree.
Once students enter the work force, employers may not want to take a risk on a non-accredited student.
Also, accredited institutions often have higher levels of graduation rates, which is beneficial to both students and the schools themselves.
A school that is accredited can also help students in the job market, giving them an edge over others who do not have this level of accreditation.
Accreditation status and the quality of instruction are an important part of a college’s reputation among potential students. A college’s reputation is highly valued because it speaks to the institution’s commitment to both its students and to the community.
By showing their parents that their child is attending a good school, they are sending the message that they care about the students and that they are committed to their children’s success.
If a college is not accredited, it is impossible for a student’s family to feel confident that their child is prepared to enter the work force after graduation.
Many parents choose not to enroll their children in an institution that is accredited because of safety.

Post by: TheGSMoeller on July 17, 2019, 08:18:37 AM
Quote from: Necrosis on July 16, 2019, 11:37:33 AM
To be honest, I still have many unanswered questions regarding Drones, especially due to the various versions of the record that have come out over the years, so many of the thoughts I'm going to share here may end up changing in the future as I have more time to really think about the album.
For the time being, this is what I have to say after a year worth of reflection:
I feel like the album's themes of social-political discontent, loneliness, and isolation as well as the various emotional and personal narratives and experiences that run through it all speak to a larger audience than the album's (apparent) focus on suicide may let on. The album also seems focused more on the individual experience and the personal as opposed to the broader themes of social and institutional structures, power, and corruption.
While Drones is absolutely a great album, in my opinion, if you just play Drones' songs individually and leave out the concept (or lack-thereof) tying them all together, it's not all that remarkable since it's not atypical of the band. It's only when it's conceptualized as a piece and considered in the context of the other records that it becomes special.

Post by: TheGSMoeller on August 04, 2019, 04:27:27 PM
It's not my thing though I'd like to learn more about the concept and lyrics. I appreciate and appreciate Tool's craft a lot; my taste for the band overall though is kind of minimal.
I can dig these songs a lot when their lyrics actually mean something, though? The lyrics of most Tool songs aren't really that interesting to me, but in a song like this one, it actually means something (most of the time, anyway)? And I can appreciate that as an interesting challenge, and even appreciate that Tool is probably the biggest rock/metal band to make doing it cool (but like, only a tiny bit).
But I'm not really that interested in the actual music of Tool's music, which is why I was always more of a fan of A Perfect Circle than anything.
The songs themselves I'm not that big a fan of either, but there's a little something for me in the way they're recorded and I can appreciate the ambition and the craft that went into it. If you've seen the band live (or you've been paying attention), though, it's interesting to see that the live arrangements, and the arrangements of the songs that were originally recorded with a full symphonic orchestra, aren't all that different from what a rock band normally sounds like live. They're a bit more amped-up in their dynamics, sure, but not terribly far afield from what other rock and metal bands do? I haven't seen A Perfect Circle live, but as an arrangement for a band in a studio setting, I'm not seeing a reason why they couldn't do something like this.
Maybe I should see them, especially considering that Adam Jones is probably getting better than ever, what with this new album, since he's had to step up a little bit as a guitarist in the wake of Justin Chancellor's departure from the band.

Post by: TheRam on December 08, 2019, 06:09:59 AM
Got here to share my thoughts on Fear Inoculum.
It's been a week since I first heard it and the album is still on repeat :)
The songs are incredibly wellcrafted, there's a ton of references in there and the whole album is a celebration of Tool's trademarks plus some new elements:
- a ton of ambience (my favourite one is probably the title track)
- beautiful textures and effects
- weird vocals (not quite as insane as on Schism, for instance)
- lots of atmosphere
My main complaint with the album after a few weeks was that the songs are almost all in the same "template", but as I listened to several times the instrumental work, melodies and song structure, they became just a pleasure to listen. I also enjoy the melodic guitar riffs and the bass in the songs is also something special :)
There's some songs that are less memorable than the others (Rosetta Stoned, the title track and Invincible are the ones mostly played), but I still think the album is really fucking good and it could be at the top of a short list of the best rock/metal albums of all times.
P.S.: 69-minute album is a little bit to long, but not too much :)
It's always a pleasure to hear new music from my fav bands (especially when their work rate is still so high).

10 Chapter 1 What Do We Mean by Multilingual Classrooms? There is a growing interest among educations in developing multilingual classrooms; however, the term “multilingual” has been used in a variety of different ways and is often perceived as a threat to educational standards and outcomes. What is a multilingual classroom? Before discussing multilingual classrooms, it is important to distinguish different types of multilingual environments. Researchers generally agree that schools and classrooms that teach different languages should be characterized as multilingual, as opposed to bilingual or monolingual schools. ֳ����� &ֳ��������" ��' '�' &�����, & �''��
11 Classrooms should be characterized based on their instructional design rather than the languages that are taught. Bilingual schools offer education completely in a non-dominant language, which is often the mother tongue (or majority language). Such schools can be found in South Africa, Europe, or the United States (see www.bilingualschools.org). A monolingual classroom is defined more by the target language of instruction rather than the language(s) used at home by the students. There are two main kinds of monolingual classrooms: monolingual schools, which consist of a single native English-speaking community, and schools where majority-language classes and monolingual English classes are combined. Examples of an English-medium majority-language and English classes can be seen in the case studies included in this book. Monolingual English classrooms have been promoted as a model for multilingual classrooms. A multilingual classroom is a classroom with multiple languages, with each language having an equal value and equal status in the eyes of both the teachers and students. It differs from a bilingual classroom in that English is a foreign language in the multilingual classroom, whereas in a bilingual environment, it is a language in daily use by students. Students do not need to “give up” any of their native languages; in fact, English is acquired as a foreign language. A monolingual classroom is not a realistic option for most schools and communities. Furthermore, bilingual and monolingual classrooms have proven to be socially unstable and culturally isolating, not to mention expensive. Thus, the growing interest in the teaching and learning of multiple languages in schools is largely based on multilingual classrooms. It is important to note that the idea of multilingual classrooms has both linguistic and cultural components. It implies that students bring their native and home languages to school as an asset rather than a language deficiency or barrier to learning. In such environments, students work and learn in more than one language, developing a linguistic and cultural awareness, and acquiring more than one way of thinking about languages and about language learning. Classrooms become centers for the acquisition, use, and development of linguistic and cultural diversity rather than sites for the erasure or incompatibility of those factors. Multilingualism within the classroom requires a specific educational design as well as a supportive social and cultural climate, which is what we call a “multilingual classroom” (see Figure 1.1). Figure 1.1 The multilingual classroom model includes the linguistic and cultural dimensions of diversity in learning. For educators, developing multilingual classrooms means taking into account how students’ linguistic (such as their native and home languages) and cultural (such as their ethnicity or migration status) backgrounds can help to structure the teaching and learning of the academic material covered. This approach to teaching and learning seeks not only to maximize the benefits of diversity but also to minimize the potential costs of multilinguism. In other words, it seeks to mitigate the potential adverse effects of learning in more than one language. These include dissonance, where one feels “out” of one’s language, and double consciousness, where one has to “re-learn” oneself through the study of more than one language. For children, these conditions can lead to feelings of alienation and isolation. For teachers, they can present challenges of management and implementation, as well as create conflicts with the goals of teaching academic content. Conversely, it is possible to take positive, transformative approaches to learning in multilingual contexts through the use of critical multilingual literacy. One key question concerning multilingual classrooms is about their relationship with English instruction. In 1999, the US Supreme Court ruled in the case of Lau vs. Nichols that English-only instruction and testing in a school environment do not constitute a violation of civil rights laws, since federal law does not demand native-speaking competency of students for admission to and enrollment in public schools. However, there is no law that guarantees English-only instruction or restricts the implementation of a policy of language diversity in the school. As a result, most education systems in the US and other multilingual societies (such as Australia, Canada, Indonesia, and Spain) have a policy of “additional languages,” which allows for the teaching of a second language, often English in this context, beyond the mother tongue. However, there is great variation in the specificity of the language policy. Some schools offer one additional language, while others offer many. Some schools make the choice to teach both a second and a third language, while others prefer to give priority to the two languages traditionally used. Some prefer learning a foreign language, while others prefer to adopt a multilingual approach that enables children to use and develop both home languages and their additional languages. Many also prefer to teach English within the context of academic subjects rather than as a foreign language. This second approach raises another question: Should English be learned as an additional language, or as a fourth or fifth one? When English is used as a foreign language outside the context of academic subjects in multilingual classrooms, this is usually known as “content-based instruction” (CBI). CBI is defined as the teaching of a subject (such as reading, language, and mathematics) entirely in the target language. English classes typically constitute the majority of content area learning in schools, particularly if English is the additional language, as it is for the vast majority of the students in our sample schools. It is no surprise, then, that English serves as the pivot or reference language in most multilingual learning contexts. This book will explore multilingual classrooms in which English is taught as a content area subject. The most important difference between a monolingual classroom and a multilingual classroom is that multilingual classrooms are characterized by more than one language. They are a result of the interaction between cultural, national, and linguistic resources of the students, the teacher, the curriculum, and the pedagogical resources available for teaching. The development of multilingual literacies requires that teachers and learners reflect on and adapt a range of linguistic and cultural resources based on shared and differential goals (Dillard, 2003). Thus, this book is a practical guide for teachers who want to bring multilingual approaches to their classrooms (for more detailed discussions and examples, see the case studies at the end of the book). The first section focuses on theoretical and practical issues related to creating and maintaining successful multilingual classrooms. Chapter 2 explores different models of multilingual classrooms; Chapter 3 looks at a range of possible policies about multilingualism; Chapter 4 gives the language profile of most of the participating schools, as well as advice about designing, planning, and implementing a multilingual classroom; Chapter 5 discusses the challenges and potential obstacles of implementing a multilingualist approach; and Chapter 6 describes the importance and benefits of bilingual research. From such a base, the rest of the book focuses on the classroom and how the issues mentioned above can be addressed in the multilingual classroom. Part 2 includes a chapter exploring the process of designing and implementing an ESL and/or ELD, or content-based, classroom approach; Chapters 8, 9, and 10 discuss the particular issues that may arise in the implementation of these approaches for different grade levels. Finally, Part 3 includes a chapter that describes a multilingual approach to assessing, evaluating, and reporting (which can also be used for an ELD classroom); a chapter presenting examples of actual classroom materials, lessons, and activities; and two more case studies that illustrate ELD and content-based instruction in action.
13 Classroom Issues 1 Introduction Multilingualism, and especially multilingual education in schools, is a highly controversial issue in many parts of the world today. Some are supportive of bilingual (and trilingual) education in response to rising levels of immigration and a change in the demographics of many nations. Others are against such a policy on grounds that it represents a dilution of national culture. Some argue that such programs can create second-class citizens (Raizada, 2000). Others, for example those involved in content-based instruction (CBI), argue that multilingual education is a necessary support to the success of the academic subjects for second-language learners. In such situations, all sides tend to use the same arguments against and for multilingual education and fail to discuss what we think multilingual education should accomplish. In this introduction we try to focus this debate on three broad areas: multilingual classrooms, multilingualism, and teaching/learning English in multilingual contexts. Multilingual classrooms Multilingual classrooms are characterized by the instruction of more than one language, with each language having an equal value and equal status in the eyes of both the teachers and the students. As we saw in our discussion of multilingualism in Chapter 1, a classroom should be characterized based on the instructional design rather than the languages that are taught. Bilingual schools offer education completely in a non-dominant language, which is often the mother tongue (or majority language). Such schools can be found in South Africa, Europe, or the United States (see www.bilingualschools.org). The main purpose of such schools is to reduce cultural isolation of minority students. In some cases these schools are “drop out factories,” and students often go on to “mainstream” education. A monolingual classroom in which English is the major language for learning and instruction is prevalent. Many countries, including Canada, Australia, the UK, and the US, have implemented a kind of bilingual policy in which schools teach multiple languages but students go to the monolingual English class. The idea of promoting bilingualism in a monolingual environment, however, often turns out to be less than satisfactory. One can make use of more than one language in a country and still be exclusively monolingual if the non-dominant languages are not given a dominant role in communication, such as in the classroom. For example, in some countries, students receive instruction in two or three languages (usually in the home language, followed by the majority or official language). Because such an environment is monolingual, students can switch languages without realizing that they are doing any such thing. One can do bilingual instructional programs in monolingual classrooms, but this is not enough, because it is a case of language learning as a second skill and not as a first language with academic content. To make matters worse, in countries with high levels of migration, the majority-language speakers often feel that they are being asked to speak the language of their minority neighbors. This can lead to language conflicts, which can end in segregated schooling, if not in more severe situations. 13 Multilingualism is not the same as multilingual instruction. In fact, it is possible to receive multilingual instruction in a completely monolingual environment. Multilingual classrooms may be a step away from the monolingual situation if they are not monolingual but are instruction in a single foreign language. To avoid the above problems with the two-language programs described above, countries can implement policies supporting a monolingual minority language and minority languages for immigrants and other marginalized groups. There are two kinds of monolingual classrooms —monolingual English classrooms in the English-speaking community; and monolingual majority-language classes and English-only instruction in the immigrant schools in the United States (for more elaborate debates in this field, see chapter by Ruehl, Slee, and Stansell; chapter by Vaughan). The majority-language classes and monolingual English classrooms have been promoted as a model for multilingual education. The problem here is that the term “multilingual” can be misrepresented —it can mean many different things because many stakeholders, including teachers, administrators, and policy makers, use it in very different ways. According to the United States Department of Education, “A truly multilingual school, however, is one where all three dimensions of language learning are emphasized equitably: English as a learner language, a first language that is valued for its linguistic and cultural importance, and as a learner’s language of academic study” (Nagy, 1995). Such a school is more likely to be successful with many types of students, especially those who need extra language support. In addition to a majority-language class, bilingual schools, and the majority-language classes with English-medium instruction, there are a range of programs teaching two languages at the early years levels. These different programs are designed to meet the needs and requirements of learners who are already proficient in English and use it in the outside environment. In some cases, teachers work in a majority-language classroom in an immigration school or a monolingual immigrant school. These classrooms are designed for a particular type of student, namely those who need extra support in English language development. Multilingualism According to the term used by the United Nations, this refers to “multilingualism, which takes different forms in different parts of the world, is the characteristic by which every individual belongs to different linguistic groups” (UNESCO, 1998). This does not mean that every student has equal skill with every language. It refers rather to each individual’s native, cultural, and personal linguistic resources and heritage. As such, it is quite a different concept from multilingual classrooms, in which students do not necessarily all have the competencies that all teachers want, no matter what language they use in their different interactions. Multilingual classrooms mean that students have different combinations of proficiencies. Multilingualism is not the same as multilingual instruction. It is not a policy but rather a phenomenon or a situation —a situation in which many students come to the classroom with a range of skills in different languages and bring home different messages from different interactions. It is also a situation in which different home and community languages continue to be valued, supported, and promoted. As we will discuss in Chapter 6, it is much easier for teachers to work in a multilingual classroom if they have a good understanding of multilingualism. This means that teachers need to work at two levels: on their own understanding of multilingualism, how it works from the sociological and cognitive perspectives, and on how it is related to their individual instructional and personal approach to classroom teaching; and on working with their understanding of multiple languages and cultures in their own classroom as it is developed interactively through classroom design, lesson planning, and teaching-learning processes. Teaching/learning English in multilingual classrooms This chapter focuses on the teaching of English (or a second or other foreign language) in a multilingual context, including CBI contexts and the teaching of English as the additional language. The chapter deals with what strategies, approaches, and teaching materials and techniques are preferred, both by teachers and students, as well as by many researchers across the world. In Chapter 2, we review the basic linguistic approaches that underlie the selection and use of teaching materials and techniques such as translanguaging, code switching, and code mixing. In Chapter 3, we explore the major models of bilingual classrooms, including add-on bilingual instruction (Chavez & Valdez, 1986; Valdés, 1990); developmental bilingual instruction (Baker, 1989; Jiménez, 1989, 1991); immersion (Lederer, 1995; Valdés & Frost, 1996; Willig, 1992); linguistic maintenance (Montoya, 1977; Rosales, 1977); and the “one-language model” (Lipski & Johnson, 1984; Wexler, 1977). We also explore recent attempts to develop pedagogical materials for multilingual instruction that respond to teachers’ needs, especially by taking into account specific teaching and learning issues (Kibler, 1997; Kibler & Seltzer, 1994a, 1994b; Kibler, Seltzer, & Dix, 1988; Rauzon, 1997, 1999, 2001; Schwartz, 1987; Weems & Singer, 1988; Wilson, 1990). For most educators, developing such materials, especially those that can be used in mainstream and CBI contexts, requires a deep understanding and awareness of educational practices, classroom instruction, and learning processes. This is especially true when one takes into account the diverse instructional approaches in the field (Sparks, 1998; Tomlin, 1994; White-Smith, 1985) and the fact that even the definitions of English for Additional Language (EAL), English as a Second Language (ESL), and English as a Foreign Language (EFL) can differ for different national contexts. In Chapter 4 we give the language profile of the majority of the participants in the study and of the multilingual classrooms we focus on the pedagogical materials. generated_output:
ַ& បន្ថែមលងមានអំណោយសារ សិល្បប្រាក់ទំនិញ សិល្បប្រាស់ពិឆ្នាំ ទំនិញ នាយកនយលិម័យ សិល្បប្រាក់ នាយកណ្ឌិត សិល្បប្រាស់ ប្រវត្តិ ដែលបានប្រឡុងផ្លាញ ប្រធាភិ ពិភពលោក ប្រចាំថ្ងៃថ្ងៃហើយពិរីរពលោក នាយករដ្ឋមន្រ្តី លើក កងប្រើប្រញ្ញាណ ការអចល្បែងយនោះ (World Bank) សម្តេចកម្ពុជា ហើយ តាម សមាគម ប្រផងដ៏ប្រជុំបទឧត្ដមចិត្ត ទៅអត្ថបទឆៅយេះដ៏ឈ្មោះសារ សិល្បប្រាស់និតិពលោកបានជ្រើសរើសាលនេះ ត្រូវធ្វើជូនជោគាល់ជាលោកគឺបានទ្រពល្លទៅលើករួមហាធារញ់ងភាព ទាំងអតីត ទើបត្រូវបង្ហារកិច្ចដើម្បីឈ្មោះគ្របាលសារពិរីរបប្រទេសប្រពូសទៅផ្ទាល់ផែនភូមិលទេ កម្មវិធីនាយកនយលិម័យចូលលេខកងកម្មកម្មសាសន៍សំរីវជូនសម្បភាព ដែលបានឈួលពីចោពដល់ ប្រព័ន្ធ ស្រូវទ᠀តល់ សរុបផ្លូវ កម្ពុជា សមាគម ជូនជោគាល់បានជួបបង្ក្រាម សារ ពលោកអ្នកជម្រើសចិត្តបញ្ចប់ថ្លៃថ្ងៃហើយវាទៅស្រឱកំណាត់ ទាំង មិតុត្រី បាញ់ឤូវជប៉ុន (Goldman Sachs) មានប្រភេទផោម្ផុងពិវែងសេចុបនិស្ងស្រី នកករ កម្ពុជាក្រុមអនាគតសកល ដោយផ្សែរ ពិការ និង លើកទើបជួបហៅបញ្ចុប្បន្ន. ថោយខាតខាងមក សម្គាល់ ប្រព័ន្ធាស់ উপস���រមនុស្សនᫍୟ និង កទីខាងកើត រដ្ឋមន្រ្តី បង្ក្រាមម្ពុលកម្ពុជា រដ្ឋមន្រ្តីសាសនាខណ្ឌ សីហាសារ បីច្រ្បាច់ទ្រសួង ប្រទេស កម្ពុជា (Cambodia) យេ រដ្ឋាភិបាលសេរាដី កម្ពុជា (RAD of CAMBODIA) LBDC Cambodia សមាគម បណ្តាភិបាលការងារខាងមុខខេត្តកំពត ដើម្បីស្ថានតែបង្ក្រាម ក្រុងប្រទេសកម្ពុជា អតម័លដើម្បីតម្លៃ ប្រាយឆាប់ជ័យ ផាត់តែមួយក្រុានថ្លៃាចកាន់ ស្គាល់ សម្ឋានការូបចើប ប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ រដ្ឋាភិបាលប្រាក់រដ្ឋមន្រ្តីនិងព្រមបានជួបអន្តរាគមន៍ (World Bank Group) ដើម្បីក្រុមជ័យក្រសួងប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ គណបក្សការយោធងផ្តួលខេត្តបាត់ត្តរ រដ្ឋាភិបាលឃសិសម្មប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ ឈ្មោះ សារ សិល្បប្រាស់ដង្ឃកសោធ្ខភារ ពគ្គំបងាររពេលគុណ៕ខ្សែរឺឥលនេះ ឥង្លៀ រស់ មិនធ្វើ.
